The biggest problems with vegetarianism or vegan-ism especially on a global scale is that different people have different dietary needs. And not all those needs can be met with just a plant based diet. The big nutrients that we need meats for are proteins and iron. The biggest sources of plant based proteins are also some of the most common and severe food allergies. Our bodies are much better at processing iron from animals than from plants, and also do a better job of processing plant iron when it is also processing meat iron. Thats why so many vegetarians struggle with anemia.

While we do need to reduce consumption of meat, it would be more practical to change industrial agricultural practices to be gentler on the environment than to eliminate meat from everyone’s diet.

Balanced diet and multiculture farms have been proven most efficient for thousands years.
Humans eat the grain, animals eat the hay. Manure is used to fertilize the soil.
Eating vegetables and fruits in spring, eating fish and meat in winter. No need to transport fresh vegetables from tropical countries.
Balanced diet is environmentally friendly and economically sustainable.
Nothing beats meat ❤️

0:01 1 – you or someone you know is a vegetarian. So, we thought we’d try a thought experiment. What would happen if everyone in the world was suddenly a vegetarian? What effect would it have on our lives and the planet?

0:12 2 – Before we begin, full disclosure: none of us at ASAP Science are vegetarians and the worldwide rate of vegetarianism is fairly low, ranging from about 4 to 5 percent in the U.S. and Canada to a little over 30% in India. As a result, there are currently about 20 billion chickens, 1.5 billion cows, over a billion sheep and nearly a billion pigs in the world.

0:34 3 – Without any meat-eating humans to provide a market, whole herds of domestic animals would disappear. And this would free up vast quantities of land. About 33 million square kilometers of land are used for pasture; an area about the size of Africa. And that’s not even counting the land used to grow crops exclusively for animal feed.

0:54 4 – Some of it would be needed for the increased amount of vegetable crops, but much of the land currently used for pasture is actually too dry to grow crops. Without humans adding artificial nutrients, this land could turn to desert. But if properly managed, it’s possible that some farmland would return to its natural state of grassland or forest which could help counteract global climate change.

1:15 5 – After all, the loss of CO2 absorbing trees cleared for agriculture is a major reason why global levels of CO2 are going up. Cows and other grazers also affect our climate through large amounts of methane production which has 25 times more potential planet warming power than CO2. Combined with the loss of forests and other effects, livestock production is responsible for about 15% of global greenhouse gas emissions which is more than all the world’s planes, trains and automobiles put together.

I've become a vegetarian a year ago, after a serious amount of thinking. I love animals and being a vegetarian lets me be sure that I don't hurt any or at least hurt them as little as possible. I hate animal cruelty and people who don't care about global warming etc... Also, being a vegetarian is good for the climate and I wanted to help. Finally, I knew that my health would benefit from this change. That was the best choice I've ever made. I do have to be careful to get enough protein but I love my new lifestyle! I feel so much healthier!
The only thing is, I live in a small village where almost everyone hunts regularly and they just don't understand vegetarianism, thus sometimes insulting me for being one and accusing me of eating all the vegetables the animals need and by doing so "stealing" food from them (It's not like I eat grass!) At first, these accusations pulled me down but as I grew more convinced in my cause I didn't care so much anymore. I love being a vegetarian!

P.S This doesn't mean that I hate non-vegetarian people :)

Hi there,

I, personally, would recommend to opt out of consuming animal products (protein) as animal protein is the cause of nearly all diseases, from gathered information e.g mad cow disease and tuberculosis, that are on the rise. Cows milk, for instance, is for calves and not mankind. Furthermore, fish like wild salmon and tuna ought to be avoided due to radiation in the seas (mercury affecting tuna too). Farmed fish too should be avoided as they may lack nutrients e.g farmed salmon may lack Omega 3 Fatty Acids obtained from algae by wild salmon in the seas.

I do encourage to adopt (even if it means making small changes here and there) a well-planned, organic, unrefined and untempered with vegan diet (consuming raw plant foods where possible so as not to denature or destroy the life-forces and enzymatic activities beneficial to the human system. If disagreeing on this matter, please take some steamed carrots, plant them and see if they will grow; if not, it is because they are 'dead' plant food that cannot benefit one's 'living' cells) consisting of organic fruits, vegetables, legumes, nuts, seeds and whole grains as it is the best diet to provide mankind with ultimate health and longevity. I do not even see a reason to use pharmaceutical supplements e.g Vitamin D is obtainable from organic chestnut mushrooms (UV exposed) and sun-dried mushrooms with the exception of the body's ability to make it (and store it for future use) when exposed to the sun; Iron from organic beets; Zinc from organic cashew nuts; potassium and magnesium from organic bananas; Omega 3 Fatty Acids (beneficial for the brain) from organic walnuts and pecans (looks like the brain and targets it).

Please avoid factory produced meat alternatives whose chief ingredient can be 'soy' and may contain preservatives as well as additives (e.g Vinegar, a corrosive agent). Food toxicity and nutrient deficiency are a deadly combination as one is hindering the body's building materials needed to action healing whilst at the same time taxing the system with more toxic stuff, thus bringing about disease and possibly even an early death.

Please make sure to watch some good content on my YouTube Channel that i believe will be very helpful in transitioning into a healthy vegan successfully.

Please note:
[1] America is going to have a civil war due to food shortage not long from now.
[2] Climate Change will lead to Sun-day Laws.

Best wishes

For those of you who are wondering:
Lacto Ovo Vegetarian: Don't eat meat. (They do eat eggs).
Lacto Vegetarian: Excludes meat AND eggs.
Ovo Vegetarian: Excludes meat and dairy, but eats eggs. (Ovo means eggs btw).
Vegan: Excludes meat and everything that comes from meat.
Pescetarian: Excludes all meat except for seafood.
There are probably;y more, but these are just what I know.

Vegetarians consume dairy & milk products.

About dairy.

Cows in the dairy industry, arguably, live more miserable lives than cows raised for meat. This is because they are exploited throughout their lives for their milk and then killed.

Given that cows only produce milk only when they’re pregnant, the process begins with forced artificial insemination of cows. Farmers insert their arms into the sexual orifice of cows and pump bull semen into them. This is a necessary step for milk production and occurs in small family farms all the way to factory farms.

Once the cow gives birth, two things may happen. If the baby is male, he’s of no use for the farmers since he’ll never produce milk. Therefore, the baby is either killed at the farm, or sold to the veal industry for meat. If the baby is female, then she’ll endure the same future as her mother, going through several cycles of emotional and physical abuse. In both cases, the calves get taken away soon after birth, and mother cows tend to cry for days after their baby is stolen.

After about two or three milking cycles, the cow’s milk production rate becomes unprofitable, so the cow is killed. At this stage, the cow is usually six years old. The natural lifespan of a cow is around twenty years.

About eggs.

In the egg industry, only females are required since males cannot lay eggs. So at the hatcheries, male and female chicks are separated as they pass through a conveyor belt.

Males are considered useless so they are either killed at the hatchery (either by being macerated alive, drowned or suffocated) or thrown into the bin alive. Females are painfully de-beaked and sent off to farms, where they will lay a painful 300+ eggs per year due to genetic manipulation (as opposed to a wild chicken’s 20 or so per year). This process happens on any farm, regardless of it being free-range, organic or whatever.

After hens stop producing eggs at a profitable rate, they are sent to slaughter, which involves being thrown into an electric bath to be stunned, then hoisted up upside down and going along a conveyor belt to have their throats slit. Many chickens will remain fully conscious after their throats are slit and will be boiled alive in the de-feathering tank afterwards. Their slaughter happens at around two years of age. The natural lifespan of a chicken is eight years.

1 – Chances are, you or someone you know is a vegetarian. So, we thought we’d try a thought experiment. What would happen if everyone in the world was suddenly a vegetarian? What effect would it have on our lives and the planet?

2 – Before we begin, full disclosure: none of us at ASAP Science are vegetarians and the worldwide rate of vegetarianism is fairly low, ranging from about 4 to 5 percent in the U.S. and Canada to a little over 30% in India. As a result, there are currently about 20 billion chickens, 1.5 billion cows, over a billion sheep and nearly a billion pigs in the world.

3 – Without any meat-eating humans to provide a market, whole herds of domestic animals would disappear. And this would free up vast quantities of land. About 33 million square kilometers of land are used for pasture; an area about the size of Africa. And that’s not even counting the land used to grow crops exclusively for animal feed.

4 – Some of it would be needed for the increased amount of vegetable crops, but much of the land currently used for pasture is actually too dry to grow crops. Without humans adding artificial nutrients, this land could turn to desert. But if properly managed, it’s possible that some farmland would return to its natural state of grassland or forest which could help counteract global climate change.

5 – After all, the loss of CO2 absorbing trees cleared for agriculture is a major reason why global levels of CO2 are going up. Cows and other grazers also affect our climate through large amounts of methane production which has 25 times more potential planet warming power than CO2. Combined with the loss of forests and other effects, livestock production is responsible for about 15% of global greenhouse gas emissions which is more than all the world’s planes, trains and automobiles put together.

6 – In fact, many scientists believe that reducing meat consumption may be one of the best strategies for managing climate change. A vegetarian diet would also greatly reduce water consumption. Around 70% of global freshwater consumption is used in agriculture. It takes 15,000 litres to make a kilogram of beef, 6,000 litres for pork and 4,000 litres for chicken.

7 – Compare this with 1,600 litres for cereal crops, 900 litres for fruit and 300 litres for garden vegetables. Of course, a kilogram of meat packs many more calories than the equivalent weight of fruit but even if you compare the ratio of water per calorie of available food energy, beef is still 5 times more water intensive than fruit, 7 times more than veggies and 20 times more than cereal.

8 – So, are there any downsides to a vegetarian diet? Well, we’d be left without a cheap source for many bi-products of livestock like leather from animal hides or animal fats which are used in cosmetics, candles and detergents. And while vegetable-based alternatives do exist, their production would need to increase, meaning more land dedicated to growing crops and less restored to its natural state.

9 – A more complicated fact is that raising and processing animals is a full-time job for more than 1 billion people, most of whom are small scale farmers in the developing world. Well, some may be able to move to producing milk or eggs, or even growing vegetable crops, many would be faced with their way of life becoming obsolete. Of course, any increase in vegetarianism is likely to be a gradual process rather than a sudden cut off.

10 – And surprisingly, the trends are actually in the opposite direction. In places like India and China, people are becoming wealthier and as a result, consuming more meat which effectively cancels out the declines we see in other countries. So, we actually tried to go vegetarian for 21 days straight as an experiment in our new ASAP Thought episode.

11 – Check out the video if you want to see how it went, what we learned in the process and how we felt about it both mentally and physically. And subscribe for more weekly science videos.

I used to be that guy who would tease vegetarians. I thought I'd never become one myself and give up meat just because it was too tasty. But that was the only reason I was eating it. Having a dog has taught me a lot about animal intelligence. My dog definitely feels all the same things as I do. Pain, joy, sadness, anger. One day i decided to open mindedly accept what I saw in a documentary without my mental meat loving barrier up. Discovering that pigs are more intelligent than dogs really made me start to see more clearly. I saw pigs in cages so small they couldn't even turn around, and piglets getting castrated without any anesthetics. And I could see the fear in their eyes and hear their screams. I saw the same fear in cows as well. I imagined for a moment, what if that was my dog in there with a thousand others just like him. From there I just decided that taste wasn't a worthy enough reason for me to continue eating meat. I've drastically reduced the consumption of diary products over time and it seems that a vegan lifestyle is not as bad as it once appeared.

Lets all go vegetarian

Chances are, you or someone you know is a vegetarian. So, we thought we’d try a thought experiment. What would happen if everyone in the world was suddenly a vegetarian? What effect would it have on our lives and the planet?

2 – Before we begin, full disclosure: none of us at ASAP Science are vegetarians and the worldwide rate of vegetarianism is fairly low, ranging from about 4 to 5 percent in the U.S. and Canada to a little over 30% in India. As a result, there are currently about 20 billion chickens, 1.5 billion cows, over a billion sheep and nearly a billion pigs in the world.

3 – Without any meat-eating humans to provide a market, whole herds of domestic animals would disappear. And this would free up vast quantities of land. About 33 million square kilometers of land are used for pasture; an area about the size of Africa. And that’s not even counting the land used to grow crops exclusively for animal feed.

4 – Some of it would be needed for the increased amount of vegetable crops, but much of the land currently used for pasture is actually too dry to grow crops. Without humans adding artificial nutrients, this land could turn to desert. But if properly managed, it’s possible that some farmland would return to its natural state of grassland or forest which could help counteract global climate change.

5 – After all, the loss of CO2 absorbing trees cleared for agriculture is a major reason why global levels of CO2 are going up. Cows and other grazers also affect our climate through large amounts of methane production which has 25 times more potential planet warming power than CO2. Combined with the loss of forests and other effects, livestock production is responsible for about 15% of global greenhouse gas emissions which is more than all the world’s planes, trains and automobiles put together.

6 – In fact, many scientists believe that reducing meat consumption may be one of the best strategies for managing climate change. A vegetarian diet would also greatly reduce water consumption. Around 70% of global freshwater consumption is used in agriculture. It takes 15,000 litres to make a kilogram of beef, 6,000 litres for pork and 4,000 litres for chicken.

7 – Compare this with 1,600 litres for cereal crops, 900 litres for fruit and 300 litres for garden vegetables. Of course, a kilogram of meat packs many more calories than the equivalent weight of fruit but even if you compare the ratio of water per calorie of available food energy, beef is still 5 times more water intensive than fruit, 7 times more than veggies and 20 times more than cereal.

8 – So, are there any downsides to a vegetarian diet? Well, we’d be left without a cheap source for many bi-products of livestock like leather from animal hides or animal fats which are used in cosmetics, candles and detergents. And while vegetable-based alternatives do exist, their production would need to increase, meaning more land dedicated to growing crops and less restored to its natural state.

9 – A more complicated fact is that raising and processing animals is a full-time job for more than 1 billion people, most of whom are small scale farmers in the developing world. Well, some may be able to move to producing milk or eggs, or even growing vegetable crops, many would be faced with their way of life becoming obsolete. Of course, any increase in vegetarianism is likely to be a gradual process rather than a sudden cut off.

10 – And surprisingly, the trends are actually in the opposite direction. In places like India and China, people are becoming wealthier and as a result, consuming more meat which effectively cancels out the declines we see in other countries. So, we actually tried to go vegetarian for 21 days straight as an experiment in our new ASAP Thought episode.

11 – Check out the video if you want to see how it went, what we learned in the process and how we felt about it both mentally and physically. And subscribe for more weekly science videos.

1. Not having animal fat or skin to create luxury items is not a downside. Not having animal byproducts means we didn't have to exploit and kill animals so we could have the fancy candles. That's an ethical upside, frankly.
2. 70% of the crops that are raised right now are set aside for feeding livestock. If there wasn't any livestock to feed, those crops could be used both to feed humans AND for the use of replacing animal byproducts for comfort items. Go on and git yourself that fancy candle!
3. If people are making a living raising and selling livestock but no one is eating animals, they won't make any money. The demand would be for crops, right? We couldn't rotate crops properly due to massive needs and thus we would deplete soil, leading to erosion and possible deserts forming.

I have vegetarian/vegan friends that eat massive portions of plants and are still having a lesser caloric intake than my small portions of a balanced diet of meats mixed in with veggies. I don't see vegetarianism as sustainable considering how much plant matter would need to be produced to feed human populations. I agree that we should lessen the amount of meat we eat, but to do away with it entirely is impractical and foolish.

What the video gets right:

- A lot of the land used for grazing does not have the adequate composition to grow crops, or at best, will grow very poor crops.

- Takes into consideration the byproducts of raised animals.

What the video gets wrong:

- Methane production by bovines is greatly increased by them eating food that is not adapted to their digestive system, like corn and soy. Bovines are meant to eat grass. As for the number of cars analogy (or whatever transportation type used), numbers vary greatly, and are not a really good indicator, since cars produce gases that are far more damaging than CO2.

- Water is shown in raw numbers, but it doesn't take into account the "colors" of water: blue, green, and gray. Raising grass-eating cattle requires a lot of green water, which is pretty much "free" water from precipitations. It is therefore misleading to simply say it takes 15000L of water to produce a kg of beef, without details on how the water is used.

- The video makes an effort to point out that calories from meat are more dense than cereal, but calories is one of the least important factor when it comes to nutrition. Things like vitamins, minerals, proteins and fats are far more important. And on that part alone, meat beats everything else.

- As for the jobs lost, well, automation is a good thing, so it's more about an economics fallacy.

Nice video except you forgot to mention that if we went vegetarian, the animals we have bred for consumption would reproduce like rabbits and become a threat. Look at deer, for example. Because we have removed their natural predators like, wolves, bears, mountain lions, etc., there is nothing controlling the population of deer, and we hardly eat them so nothing is stopping them from over populating. Deer cause hundreds of car crashes a year alone, so imagine adding chickens,  pigs, cows, and sheep to the mix. It would cause so many more fatalities and would disturb the natural cycle of life. While I agree that we really do eat too much meat, especially in the US, I also agree that there is a natural circle of life that we are a part of. Too many herbivores without enough carnivores would result in the destruction of vegetation and would kill other native species because of a lack of food. The only way to fix that problem would be to go back to eating them, or reintroducing natural predators. So unless you want to go back to having tons of wolves, bears, and mountain lions roaming around our homes and cities, we need to keep eating meat; though in moderation.

Besides we evolved the high functioning brain after we become omnivorous this is because of the greater amount of energy and nutrients the meat provided over the previous diet of just plants, after all we must remember the brain uses more energy then any other organ so what seems like a simple dietary change is actually what let us evolve to our current point without it there is a good chance our distant ancestors would of never been able to use their better evolved brain to ensure survival as they wouldn't have had the necessary energy or nutrients to produce that first spark of intelligence.

On another note something that is rarely talked about is the decrease in cognitive function you see in vegetarians and vegans, its much easier to see in vegans especially with someone who changed from a normal diet to vegan the effects aren't instant but over the next few months the changes do become noticeable. As for vegetarians it defers quite a bit between people some have only very small changes also the changes take a bit longer for them as they have at least some of what the vegans don't get any of.

The plains of the USA, Canada, and Russia were once dominated and maintained by massive herds of hooved animals. The plains and other areas once dominated by these animals are speculated to be the largest carbon sinks on the planet. But the buffalo and other megafauna are gone now and grazing animals are fenced in preventing them from doing what it was they once did of continually moving, eating down the grass, pooping all over, trampling their poop in the soil, moving on, and then returning in 3-6 months time and all the poop fertilized the soil, the eaten grass cleared the way for new grass to grow, and the cycle repeats. Look into the principles behind holistic land management.

I was vegetarian until age 7. I suffered stunted muscle development, severe allergies, and worse eyesight than my family history would suggest. I did it mostly on moral grounds. Part of my problem was likely my parents' inexperience with healthy vegetarianism.

At age 8, someone I respected took up the debate and convinced me that while eating meat might not be ideal, the effort required to maintain peoples' health with available plant crops made it not worthwhile. My first meat was a chicken drumstick. It tasted bland, but extremely filling.

Now I make my own food. I've eaten out this week while travelling, and realized that since leaving my parents and getting a job I now eat very little meat. Eating out in Louisiana due to lack of a kitchen, each meal contains more meat than I buy at home in a week.

TLDR. There are good reasons for peoples' dietary choices. Meat works best as a small addition to your diet. Remember that you are descended from the only scavengers good enough to break down petroleum ;) and don't be squeamish when we finally get tomeatos to grow on trees!

About the desertification effect of removing livestock; search up a Ted Talk called "how to fight desertification and reverse climate change". It talks about how to use livestock properly to benefit the environment.

Livestock is the greatest worldwide contributor to greenhouse gas emissions, at just over fifty percent. It is also the greatest cause of habitat loss and species extinction worldwide.

Removing meat, or at a minimum beef and diary, from our diets is, sadly, a necessary evil. Without it, we will never stay below the 2 degree mark, and millions of animal and plant species will die.

As an ominvore I have been cutting down on meat over the past year or so, and I am happy with the choice that I have made here. I am also well aware of the ecological benefits that veganism/vegetarianism brings to the table, and I do agree that a change has to be made. So some of you may find it funny that I am planning to stick to being an omnivore for as long as I live. Why?
Well I find that the main issue isn't with eating meat in general, it is rather with the meat industry. The way factory farming is being carried out is inhumane, due to the cramped conditions and the way that animals are being injected with growth hormones and antibiotics, as well as the artificial insemination needed to keep with demand. Of course, the video mentions contributions to climate change as well, so we definitely need to change how meat is being farmed.
However, telling the whole world to go vegan is not a good solution, because more problems are going to arise, some of which this video has not really mentioned. For instance approximately a third of the Earth's land is very arid and is only suitable for animal agriculture, such as in the Sahel, the Outback and the Arctic circle, so people have no choice but to eat meat to survive. Also are you sure that vegan/vegetarian life-styles are healthier? The problem is that too many people are ignorant about dieting and as a result the vast majority of meat eaters eat too much, which is what drives the results of these health studies. So if they all went vegan, they may not get enough sources of Vitamin B12, Iron and Protein due to their lack in planning what to eat. A study conducted by the University of Vienna in fact stated that meat-eaters are less likely to get cancer and heart disease than vegetarians, but that is a different result to what the WHO said. Accumulation of fatal diseases such as cancer are due to a variety of factors, such as genetics, environmental, and even stress, mood, sleep patterns, lifestyle etc. So veganism/vegetarianism does not guarantee a healthier life.
What we really need to do is encourage meat-eaters to reduce meat consumption, bit by bit, and then we should all unite and protest against how the meat industry treats the animals. That way the demand for meat will drop, and we will slowly reduce the greenhouse gas emissions from livestock, so eventually much of the land previously used for grazing will be used for crops that humans will be able to include in their diet. Be a meat eater, vegan or vegetarian if you want, but make a change in a smart and calculating way, aiming for the best of both worlds. Us humans may become completely vegan at some point, but I'll probably be dead by then (I'm in my early twenties).

I have been a vegetarian for maybe 6 years now and am now trying to go vegan. The transition was not easy at first, but eventually, my tastebuds and everything changed! There could honestly be so many great changes we could make to this earth if we stopped large scale production of meat and dairy and if we designed technology aiming for sustainable farming (ex. Sky gardens). Personally, I don't like to consume other animals, but if it ever came to a point where most of the population was vegetarian and people still wanted to consume meat and dairy, raising your own livestock could become an option. Obviously for people living in cities that would be difficult, but at the end of the day, large scale production is only destroying the Earth. I feel like people need to see what goes into their food and how it is made. With new innovations in farming, we could change how we think about food and take control of what we consume and how we treat the only Earth we have. At this rate, we may not have this Earth for much longer. Not to mention, our health issues stem from the government and companies that can basically put whatever they want into our food and find loopholes in order to distribute it. In no way would we be able to make these changes over night, but I feel like an important step is to change the way we think about our groceries and how we use our land. There are better and more efficient ways to make food. We could probably even make more food and cure world hunger. I really hope to discover some of these innovations one day.

If anyone is being vegan/vegetarian to avert suffering then they are doing it for the wrong reason. Suffering is a natural expression of the laws of our environment which is predicated upon an "prey and predator" dichotomy. Even the plants that a vegan consumes realizes it is being eaten and suffers on a very literal cognitive level (see the research conducted by the University of Missouri). Also many scientists have extensively researched plants and have concluded that they are conscious, intelligent and even emotional. Professor Stefano Mancusco who leads the International Laboratory for Plant Neurobiology states: "We are convinced that plants are cognitive and intelligent, so we use techniques and methods normally used to study cognitive animals." Plants are underestimated in that most people view them as inanimate objects which are completely unaware but this is entirely untrue.

I don't really see livestock production being much different for a vegetarian population, but the ways it would be different aren't for the better, IMO. There'd still be chickens and other poultry being farmed for eggs, and cattle, sheep, and goats for dairy. The breeds of those animals that were used for meat production would become extinct, but other than that, the (only) main livestock that we wouldn't farm anymore would be pigs. Imagine what increasing dairy and egg production actually means though... more chickens in cages and sheds, more bobby calves (that will go to waste), more feedlot dairies. Feeding grain to livestock, especially poultry, wouldn't change. Cropping and horticulture will increase, and along with it pesticide, fertilizer, and fossil fuel use. That also means more pesticide resistance, more GMOs (which I'm not necessarily against, but I know that a lot of people are), and a greater need for phosphorus, which will likely result in mining the oceans for it.

It's a complicated issue, and not something that videos like this can even get close to explaining in enough detail to give someone the ability to make an informed decision. Firstly, how the hell are you supposed to check those figures? Where did they come from? How reliable are they? Without referencing, it requires a lot of searching to find reliable figures, and most people don't bother with that, so they take the figures from videos like this as fact. In terms of communicating science, that's already a fail.

The environmental issues with agriculture are related less to WHAT we eat, and more to HOW we produce it. It's about time people started focusing on what really matters - improving our production systems - rather than choosing ones to eliminate entirely (without any understanding of the consequences of doing that).

I've been vegetarian for several years and I must say, I totally agree with you guys. I personally don't even expect people to go fully vegetarian. But what I do expect is respect for the animal that died for your food. When people buy meat they should really look at the price tag and ask themselves 'What life did this animal have? Did it live on a farm or was it a product of mass production? Am I OK with the way that animal lived? Should this animal have live that way?' and if they decide that they are OK with this (which I don't judge, I just personally don't like the taste of meat), they should go on and buy it and happily eat it. Now, I get that acting this way for many people means not being able to have meat on a regular basis but that's OK. You don't need meat everyday. Once a week is enough.
But yeah, just like I said: have respect for the animal you're eating and be aware of what you are eating. I don't expect anything else.

They missed a couple things: 1. we use antibiotics on farm animals because they act like growth hormones (ex. fat chickens). This results in antibiotic resistant infections in domestic and wild animals AND in humans. 2. Animal farming creates toxic runoffs that pour into the ocean or wetlands (swine feces has killed off fish species in US rivers!). 3. the genetically selected breeds of farm animals are susceptible to human like disease (avian flu, swine flu). 4. fishing is threatening the genetic diversity of fish stocks in oceans/rivers and destabilizing the ecosystems. 5. the total quantity of suffering in the world is higher because the 20 billion chickens are genetically mutated, suffering creatures awaiting death. They grow so quickly they get kidney failure, broken legs, ruptured spinal discs. They eat food lacking in nutrition and get infections that cause septic wounds.

In a practical sense, that means it would be very difficult to raise enough crops to feed everyone on the planet today. People would starve. Less meat consumption is good, but cutting it out all together is the wrong answer. But saying I'm doing it for ecological or sustainability reasons is just false. I do it because I really hate eating meat.

The example of managing global warming by cutting off on eating meat is sort of counterintuitive to me. Like you correctly mentioned, over a billion people are financially dependent on the animal husbandry industry, a large portion of which is dedicated to raising animals for the purpose of meat. If there is a ban on meat consumption (hypothetically speaking, of course), these people won't abandon the land they own, but rather use it to find an alternative means of livelihood. A lot of this land would be available for cheap, since agriculture and animal husbandry dominantly happens in regions like suburbs or villages (more so in countries that dominate these sectors - India, Indonesia and China, for example). Some of this free land would be inevitably bought up by industrialists who might use it as factories. Also, we would need to dedicate a lot more land to systematic agriculture to make sure that the world's growing population is continuously fed.  This would need infrastructure (mainly in terms of water and electricity that drives the water), which a lot of agricultural countries lack in. This would lead to food shortages of a scale we are not used to in this century with a billion more people entering the malnourished list in these countries, and we would witness food prices hit the roof in most countries that do not produce the goods. A lot of people living in cold regions across the world which are dependent mostly on trade for their food would perhaps verge on starvation. This is a quality video, but in my humble opinion, you should have accounted for the economic ramifications of such a move. We were hunters before we were gatherers and farmers, so we are not only genetically conditioned to eat meat (not saying we can't be vegetarians and survive), and our economy depends on us eating animals. Agree on the point that we would save a lot of fresh water, but we won't likely have use for that water if our population starves. Thanks again for the amazing content - just my two cents :)

While the entire word going vegetarian would obviously help the environment, it's not exactly realistic (at least right away). Depending on your religious views, carnivorism does appear ethically inferior. But I have two other issues;

First, the term needs to be defined better to retain the view of victimhood and the evils of carnivorous behavior. There are different kinds of vegetarianism (Hindu vs. Jainism for example) can result in people being called "carnivores" by some and "vegetarians" by others. So who is what is still in the air tonight. To try to explain: My understanding is that some Hindus can eat the root of the plant without being seen as someone who will destroy the soul of a living being. Other Hindus and Hindu-like religions (Sikhism and Jainism) can only eat the leafs, fruit, and legumes to remain ethical (in their view). One group destroys the center of life which cannot be replaced beyond reincarnation.

Second, some people need more than vegetarianism can give them. I've found I need protein and simple carbohydrates that fast food and meat diets provide. Not eating enough of one can result in a seizure for me. For twenty years nobody knew why I was in the hospital every other week. The association is casual and something the patient noticed. I cannot say this is how it works for all epileptics, it is just how it works for me. I doubt if I am alone since over 70% of epilepitics cannot be explained using current medical theories.

Going vegetarian is actually easy if you know what foods to look for
Alternative to whole milk: Almond milk, coconut milk
Alternative to meat patties: Vegetable patties
Good meatless protein sources: Lentils, Quinoa, Nuts, Beans
Good meatless carbohydrate sources: Pasta, bread, rice

Some examples of filling vegetarian (but not necessarily vegan) foods:
Bean and cheese burrito
Grilled cheese
Vege patty burger
Tofurky
Pasta mixed with boiled lentils, quinoa and steamed vegetables

Where I live, in Southern California, vegetarian products are actually more common in wealthier areas (West Los Angeles). The local Ralphs or Wholefoods usually has all of the above. In a less wealthy neighborhood, the local Smart and Final has fewer vegetarian options.

Don't become veggie because you think it's better for the environment. The amount of available food decides the amount of people that there will be. So if we all become veggie, a whole lot of food will become available. This will lead to a world in which every individual is fed well, on short term. BUT, on long term all of us being vegetarians will lead to a enormous population rise. This means MORE consumption of non-food products, which leads to more and more pollution.

Keep it simple guys, there are no 'easy' long term sollutions for the world food problem. Face it. We only want to hear fairytales of for exemple car manufacturers who tell you driving in a electrical car is good for the environment. It's complete bullshit, the industry that manufactures those cars still run on fossil fuels like gas and oil. The industry tells you to buy more. I believe the best way to deal with our problems is to keep fighting for good alternatives, but we also need to face the reality that we need to lower our consumption immediately. We cannot have infinite economic growth on a finite planet...

This planet isn't build for this many people. It is certain that a huge war is coming. There are too few resources for all of us. What do we do when the nitrate mines are depleted? Did you guys ever notice that without nitrate to fertilize our planet, this planet could only support around 1 billion people instead of 8 Billion? They don't teach that in our schools do they? And what about water? soil quality depletion? Energy supply? If interested please do research on this topic and find out yourself.

Also how many of the required energy do you think is being produced sustainable today? Perhaps enough to provide your home power for 10 minutes a day. Also, those sustainable energy sources like wind mills and solar panels are produced with fossil fuels! So we are still unable to build those without fossil fuels. We don't have nearly enough time to find a way to live like us Western people do at this moment. Prepare yourself people, stay positive. Try to help as much as you can by lowering consumption, doing research and spreading the word. do not feel unhelpful. You can change the world.

Rubber production requires animal products to be added to the rubber to give it strength. Glues (forcing us to go with more petroleum based products), even oil alternatives such as biofuels, which can be made from a number of animal fats. Not to mention products we use every day, such as shampoos, toothpaste, laundry detergents, and others.

The cattle from our farm get their water from eating grass, which got it's water from rain and they drink from slews and shallow (less than 50 ft wells), which are filled with - get this! RAIN!
And where does that water go after they used it? It leaves them as milk, pee, and water vapour from which is falls back to earth as - get this! RAIN!
Its called the Water Cycle. We learned about it in Grade 3 Science.

Now if you are talking about water poor environments that are taking their water from deep wells, that is a different story. But those are the exception not the rule. Regulate those.

Where I live there only the poor land is used for grazing, and guess what use to graze there - Bison! Now we have cows, and they drink from "Buffalo Wallows" (would have been better named Bison Wallows). Natural depression that were expanded by the use of Bison over thousands of years.
As a kid we found arrow heads and stone scrapers at the edges of these. Now our cows drink from them. And this is the norm across the prairies of Canada and the US.

Nothing wrong with being a vegetarian or vegan, but I think for continued evolution of human brains, meat is our greatest hope. To explain this we must go back to our primitive ancestors. They lacked much of our current brain capacity, and that would have remained that way without the discovery of cooking. With cooking, our bodies were able to get nutrients much easier allowing us to use more. This in turn allowed our brains to become more developed, since it takes much more nutrients and calories. This can best be illustrated by looking at other mammals. They tend to need less compared to their size.

With this in mind, I wonder, is meat our way of unlocking further cognitive capabilities? This is not a slam at vegans or vegetarians trying to call them stupid (a little disclaimer.) As is we can subside on a fully vegetarian/vegan diet with little to no know i'll effects. In the future, however, this might not be so.

Okay i have no problems with vegetarians but i do have a problem with people who antagonize people because of what they eat. First off humans are omnivorous which means we can eat both plants and meat; you aren't necessarily a bad person because you eat one or the other. Another thing technically a balanced human diet should consist of an equal ratio of both so the whole vegan vs meat eating thing shouldn't even be a thing people fight over. No other animal on the planet fights over this shit why do we? We're smarter creatures right? So why do have to make every little irrelevant thing into some massive shit storm? Also to vegans it doesn't matter what you eat plant or farm animal guess what something still dies in the process. Plants are living organisms it doesn't matter if they don't have pain receptors they still die when you digest them like any other animal. Only form of life o this planet that doesn't need to kill to eat are plants because of photosynthesis and guess what even some plants still hunt for nourishment like pitcher plants and Venus fly traps. So let's stop with that silly argument okay i'm an animal lover i love nature but that doesn't mean i have to stop eating meat to enjoy it. Things live and die that's nature if every single animal on the planet ate nothing but plants guess what? That would have a hugely negative affect on all plant ecosystems; there would be no balance land animal numbers would sky rocket but the level of evolution would drastically decrease over the course of many years. If everything is eating plants then what's the point changing a lot if your food is right there and there's no danger, no reason to change. Do you know how boring animals would be in a world like that they'd all look pretty much identical; only things that could even remotely change animals in a world like that would be weather and living conditions that's it. That's not even counting how much that make plant life decrease you know there's a reason why niches are a major thing in nature everything has it's place in the food chain. Eating meat actually helps wild life it helps to keep the ecosystem balanced and healthy. Anyway that's my long rant done this was just my view on this whole whether or not to go vegan thing. Anyone is free to do what ever the hell they want to do with their lives i just feel arguing about silly shit like this is quite frankly juvenile and a waste of time.

People rarely discuss bioavailability in the nutrition debate.  Plants can have more of certain nutrients than animal products have, but animal products are a superior quality source of certain nutrients than plants.  Vitamins and minerals from animal flesh, fat, tissue, etc, are more efficiently absorbed in the body than those from plant foods.  When it comes to nutrients it's quality over quantity.

This is bullshit. First of all, farm animal populations would first have to be slaughtered en masse so they didn't over populate and over graze, otherwise you'd have to continue adding acreage to land for continuous animal feed as the natural birthrate increased, or they'd wind up stripping all the vegetation from forest land and destroying natural habitat for wild animals, plus we'd probably all starve to death from lack of proper food sources unless these farm animals were euthanized before we reached that point. You'd honestly be saving nothing.

Case in point: There was an experiment conducted in a wildlife journal where a town banned the hunting of deer some years ago. The deer figured out the town was a safe habitat and freely walked the streets without fear of humans. The deer stripped all the leaves and bark from the trees in the surrounding area and by winter they all had to be shot because they were starving to death. The following year, the town reinstated their hunting privileges and the problem ceased.

The point is, if the entire planet became vegetarian, it would cause a lot more suffering than most of us could possibly imagine.

I'm vegetarian (Meat makes me ill). Here's the thing, if everyone would stop eating meat then the animals would become an issue. We'd need to kill them in order to take care of population otherwise the population will get too high, not enough food for them and they'd start eating each other. Most farm animals such as cows, pigs, etc will eat each other when food supply is low. Most animals will. They are mostly hunters and if they were raised in a situation where they are given food, and suddenly they aren't kept up, then there's a problem. You can't simply just realse them into the wild and expect them to control their own population. So, we would need to kill their population off completely or kill to keep the population stable. Which means we are wasting them. Which would go against most vegans/vegetarians morals.

The other, if you are truly vegan then you wont drink milk, eggs (eggs isn't meat but it's a by-product,), candy, or refuse over the counter/prescription medicine. Honey is a by-product but bees whole existence is to create it. But as a vegan you can't have any by-products, even use Wool or real leather. Most candy shells like Skittles for example uses Beetles and other insects for dyes, the FDA allows a small amount of insect product into foods because they are pretty harmless to consume. You could go outside and probably eat most species of Beetle and probably be fine. Things like pain medications use pig stomach lining, jelly have small amounts of bone marrow (non-organic jelly of course), most common medications use animal fat and other organs, stomach lining is the most common. Etc. I'm aware they make organic medicines, but that's not my point.

Going vegetarian can be healthier, for some. But not for all people. I'm on tons of supplements especially being a cancer patient, my diet is pretty strict. I am lactose intolerant so I can't drink milk or have any dairy, which means I've to take a Vitamin D and other supplements daily. If you get those gummy vitamins, they use Beetles too. And Fish Oil supplements, pretty obvious there.

You can live perfectly fine without any meat, for most people if their body can handle it, some people need that protein first hand instead. But the thing is, you can stop eating meat, everyone could stop, but you wont get away from animal byproducts. They need animal for loads of common things that are most likely in your flat at this very moment. This is how it works, these animals have given us many benefits and not just for food. If you think turning vegetarian will get rid of the cruel animal abuse in the industries, it wont, they will still be used for something whether you'll eat them or not, but instead turned into a waste. An animal being made for food is actually used very good. They will get all the good bits and use for food then send the less desirable bits to medicine industries and of course, skin them for other areas. The animal isn't being wasted. I agree, the industries can be cruel, but don;t put them all into a bag all together. I know local farmers, who are very passionate of what they do. They love their animals and try their best to make it less inhumane and do it themselves and then send all the bits to the proper places.

But I digress cause this is a shit long paragraph rant thing. I'm not judging anyone for their choices, just trying to show a bit of light. I don't want to argue, afterall I am vegetarian myself, but I just don't find someone eating meat as the greatest sin a person could do. If you want to eat meat, go for it man, you eat whatever you wanna put in your body. It's your body, do what you want. If you do want to go vegan/vegetarian, you go for it but be safe, be aware, and please research before you do it. Don't use YouTube as a reliable source, just research heavily and make sure you are doing it for YOU. No one else can tell you what to eat or what to not eat, what to not do with your own body that you have control of for your own good. We all have our morals, we all have our views, we all decide for what we do in our valuable lives. So you make that choice, for yourself and only for you. Do not feel the need that you need to do something because it's a trend or because someone else said it's the best choice. You are your own creator, do everything based on your own views and morals.

Oh wow this is such a load of nonsense. Almost everything claimed in this video isn't true. It's not a "save the Earth" scenario, it's a damned doomsday scenario.
I don't even know where to begin. First of all, to feed all of humanity with crops, it'd take more land than Earth has. Since we're far less efficient at extracting nutrients from crops than, say, cattle are. So the land that used to be used for livestock, that is farmable, assuming we let them all die, would have to be used for crops. But it can't feed the entire Earth's population. Perhaps not even a third of it so we'd have to let most of the world starve to death. All that farming would cause more damage to the environment than current livestock grazing. Global warming is pure nonsense, but everything we need to do to make that amount of farming work would wreck havoc on our rivers and oceans. It'd require far more freshwater than we currently use. We'd have to drain most aquifers and some rivers and lakes. Many aquatic species would go extinct. All the agricultural runoff would kill off many marine species too. If we didn't let all the livestock die, they'd devastate other ecosystems.
And for the cherry on top, humans can't survive on a vegetarian diet no matter what propaganda we're being spewed. There are certain proteins and other essential nutrients that your body needs that can only come from other animals because we're omnivores. Or bodies can't create them and plants do not make them either since they are not animals and don't have the same "bodies" we do and don't need them. Other animals with heavier or exclusive plant diets create them through various biological processes from different parts of plants. We do not have these processes ourselves. No carnivore does and most omnivores don't because evolutionary speaking it's more efficient for the body to lack these processes because it requires complex digestive systems that can have a lot go wrong with them that also shortens lifespan, limiting the amount of gene spreading that can be done so evolution selects against it.
The whole "healthier as a vegetarian" thing is pure nonsense. Usually, people on a vegetarian diet feel better because they cut out processed foods, and NOT because that they cut out meat. But their body cannot survive without those nutrients that are from meat only. And you can't "supplement" them because those supplements would have to come from meat, therefore livestock, anyway. Without that, your body has to literally eat itself to survive. Which will quickly kill the very young. So within two years everyone under the age of two will be dead. Within ten years, everyone that was under the age of ten. In twenty years everyone that was under the age of thirty and within thirty years every human on the planet would be dead.
Congratulations, to fulfill the wishes of your vegetarianism cult you brought humanity to extinction and left behind a devastated planet that would take millennia to recover. The exact opposite you hoped to do.

Never go vegetarian. Ever. Meat is essential to living and increases testosterone. By eating vegetarian meat (aka Tofu), you're putting phytoestrogens into your body (because tofu is literally coagulated soy milk) and will eventually lead to problems in your reproductive system.

Eating without soy is one of the hardest things I've done, because it's in everything. It's been about 2.5-3 months and it feels amazing (it feels more amazing if you do it in the 10-15 age range, which I am in right now). I'll feel amazing when all my vegan friends can fill B cups and be male (not overweight). Who's with me?

the farm animals would "disappear"? you mean, they would have to be slaughtered because no one would be able to afford to take care of them (without the prospect of selling them for food they couldn't be fed themselves).

you mention calorie density, but what about protein density and the presence of micronutrients like Vitamin B? To my knowledge, meat is by far the most economic way of ensuring people get essential amino acids, Vitamin B and protein.

Call me bias if you will (haven't eaten meat in nearly 2 years, vegan for 6 months and 99.9% sure I'll never want to be an omnivore again), but the main thing I've noticed about arguments for eating meat are often based on emotions.

I mean sometimes people talk about how vegans can't get enough protein/b12, but the main argument I've seen is an emotional one. People like being omnivores, it makes them feel good, and the idea of not eating meat is even shameful in some people.

My wife and I went vegetarian and have progressed to the point that we only eat cheese and no other dairy. So we could say that we are 95% vegan. We have been on this path for about 4 years. What made it easier for us is we started juicing vegetables in the beginning, not changing our diet from meatetarian. We allowed our bodies to dictate what they needed and within 3 months or so we found that we were off meat entirely and it has progressed from there. One must remember that making a change like that is a process. One just can't go cold turkey (no pun intended). You literally have to reframe your entire mental process, and that takes time. The benefits? I was on 13 different medicines from a series of strokes when we started. Within a year I was off ALL of those. I have also lost about 100 lbs. I feel healthier than ever and have recovered completely. So is it worth the life change? Yes, and that is just from the health aspect. My western doctors are still perplexed as to how this is even possible. (Yes, I Asian doctors). The total impact that we are making in our lives and to our planet I feel cannot be measured.

One 'negative' of humans becoming vegetarian was that "more land being dedicated to crops and less restored to its natural state" i.e. not all of the land that is currently being destroyed by animal agriculture would return to its original state but instead a giant hemp/soy farm. Firstly, even if this were to happen, it would be far more preferable to what is happening currently to the land used for animal agriculture; and secondly this directly contradicts one of your first points that plants 'could' help counteract climate change.

Another 'negative' that 1 billion people rely on animal agriculture is not only ridiculous but completely dishonest - these people are amongst the poorest in the world and is in no way comparable to first world intensive animal farming.

A couple of other major positives you have missed out include:

-Improved human health
-Oceans could recover to their natural state
-Ability to tackle world hunger - i.e. food could be reallocated to starving children rather than obese livestock
-I don't need to delve into the cruelty of the industry

The plant based starter package:
- Veggies (frozen is a great option, fresh isn't necessarily better)
- Fruit: always good to have, nature's candy. Stock up on those nanas! Also, dried fruit is a great snack as well.
- Legumes. Can't stress this enough. Crave something hearty? Grab those beans, chickpeas, lentils. Tofu is also made of legumes (soybeans) and it's super good when prepared right. If you can find it, try smoked tofu, it's very firm and smoky and a good starting point because it provides a somewhat familiar taste, it's what got me hooked on tofu!
- Nuts (also nut butters) and seeds, any kind you like to get those fats and minerals in
- Starches: grains and grain products, preferably whole, like rice, pasta, bread. Also potatoes and sweet potatoes, oh that carb-y goodness.

And you're done. If your pantry is stocked with those, you can always whip up a stir fry, curry, chili, soup, stew, pasta dish, sandwich or wrap that will be colorful, satiating, yummy and cheap. Stay with the basics. Stop focusing on "replacing" stuff. Enjoy plants for what they are, trust me, it will be amazing. (this comes from someone who though they couldn't live without dairy and chicken breasts). Hit me up if you need more ideas!

Time to type my essay, oh boy. So I believe that there's nothing wrong with a vegan, vegetarian diet at all whatever. However, unlike this odd bias towards a positive outcome from an earth of vegetarians it simply isn't that simple. This video failed to go in enough depth about the downsides. Even though pastures take up a lot of space meat also gives us more nutrients rather cheaply than plants and would subsequently require more land to grow, and as stated we simply don't have all that much soil that could sustain whatever crop we want wherever we have the space. It may help solve somewhat climate change but problems would still exist, habitat destruction exasperated by the need of more crop and the death of many animals bred for meat as their bodies have changed dramatically to the point of complete dependence. The pain these meat-bred animals would go through would far surpass the meagre slaughter of them, as that at least ends their suffering with relative speed. As I digress, meat eating isn't wrong, morally, or in terms of diet. Our bodies are built for a diverse diet and the act of cooking meat helped us early humans learn and feed more of their tribe. Killing animals have also been a base of our evolution, we must all realize and accept the fact that we are animals too, and death is a necessary evil. Death keeps animals evolving, and helps us as humans appreciate life more. However, the way we go about eating these animals need to change, it's unhealthy for everyone, and it's all to difficult to honour these poor souls. And yes, even if they were treated better we're still killing them, but they probably would be killed anyway, these animals are pretty low on the food chain. To conclude this, no diet is objectively all that much better than another. Not everyone can support these plant diets especially on a financial level or even physically due to anaemia and iron isn't easy to come across without meat. Not everyone should conform to a single diet and nobody should push these lifestyles on anyone. Tl;Dr, an all vegetarian world won't solve all our problems, this video could go into more detail, and a variety of diets is beneficial to everyone, financially, physically, and even globally.

And what about the amount of land needed to create this abundance of veggies for the 8 billion vegetarians on Earth? Since it was said in the video, not all land can produce crops as well as what we are currently using, and since fruit and vegetables don't fill your stomach with energy as much as meat products do, won't we need far more produce than we currently have? and fill far more space for crops than we use for animals?
Also what about all the companies and jobs created because of the animal farming industry, it's not just about the people who manage farm animals, but also the providers for their feed and their hides, and their by products.
My guess is that this process will take a few hundred years for it to be completed, and by then people will have genetically modified crops with the same attributes as meat once did without the negative side-affects that came with them. Also, I hate to say, "it's easier to do X", but a vegan-- and I'm saying that because removing animal herds as completely as you describe here would require everyone to be vegans, not vegetarians-- diet requires a whole lot of attention to nutrients and protein intake. If you don't pay attention to your intake and just eat veggies and fruits and grains and nuts, you'll quickly finding yourself suffering from some at the very least minor malnutrition. We can function just fine on plant proteins, but animal proteins are arguably simpler to incorporate into your diet.

(Sidenote: if everyone became vegetarians, not vegans, a whole lot more land would be dedicated to chickens because vegetarians tend to eat eggs a lot as their protein source, depending on their personal tastes of course. More eggs in total would be eaten, for sure. Anyways, we'd probably have the same amount of milking cows, though not the same amount of cows total. So yeah, for the type of change you suggest, we're talking vegans, not vegetarians. Not to mention that mass fish-farming would become even more of a thing.)

I'm not saying it's not cool to be a vegan if you want to invest the time and effort into yourself like that, and you probably will be healthier for it-- but that's your choice. Between the picky eaters of the world (for example, I have yet to find a plant protein source that I enjoy eating in large enough quantities and often-- and the nuts that I do like enough are way out of my budget), the people who don't have the time or money to be vegans without suffering from malnutrition... yeah, /worldwide/ veganism is neither a good idea nor a practical one.

I think knowing that pigs and cows and chickens feel just as much as pain as humans do, and then watching undercover slaughterhouse videos and Earthlings is what really set me off.
I still get hella cravings for meat (especially when people eat it near me), but you just have to learn to see the piece of meat as more than that... and take into account where it came from: a real live breathing animal. 2:31 was in my opinion a very weak answer to the question of the downsides to a global vegetarian diet. He says, "And while vegetable based alternatives do exist, their production would need to increase meaning more land dedicated to growing crops and less restored to its natural state." One of the major benefits to using plants instead of animals is that making food and products out of plants is way more efficient resource-wise. So, if everyone were vegetarian, sure, more land would be dedicated to growing crops, but WAY more would be freed up from the elimination of livestock. I think a more pertinent downside to the world going vegetarian would be that meat-eaters would lose out on their delicious juicy steaks and hamburgers. But as a vegan, that downside is way over my head!

In India, which has a majority of Hindu population, people are selectively vegetarian. Depending on the God you worship/the state you live in, we eat certain kinds of animals, on certain days only. I think more people  should opt to eat selectively. That way, we can reduce our consumption without fully giving it up.

Humans are naturally supposed to eat animals, but not as much as we do today. Simply it's how the food web works. Humans, along side several other species of animals, make up the top consumers. Now, we all know that vegetarians make up the 3 class of the food web, only previously followed by producers (grass, trees, shrubs etc.) and the sun. As with all animals, top consumers, or omnivores in particular, disable one species from getting an advantage over another; except Humans. Alas, we eat animals because it is essential to the steady maintenance of the balancing of the food web and to ensure our own survival. It may not seem natural, but neither is taking iron tablets to avoid iron deficiency. On top of this, we also help manage our bio systems. Some areas are beyond suitable for plants, and so generally they should be left as such. Others are not so much, and with that they should be used for

You've left out other things. For example, most of the animal species used for meat consumption would become endangered or go extinct, because their current physical attributes were developed by human selection to increase production. For example, the fluffy wool coat on sheeps was not so voluminous, and even if we stopped eating sheep meat, we'd still have to trim their wool, because they cannot survive with it. Another one, is that meat production would still exist, but be handled by criminal organizations and sold on the black market, much how it happens now with illegal meats (for example, small wild birds meat here in Italy). This way, those who would have the big money to pay for it would still eat meat, while the others too poor to circumnavigate the law would be left only with vegetables, because we'd have banned meat from ourselves.

One of the best ways to combat climate change is actually Sustainable Construction i.e. zero carbon design, smarter material choices, renewable energy sources for heating and power etc. In the UK, around 50% of CO2 emissions come from domestic and non-domestic buildings, whereas a comparatively lower 20% of CO2 emissions come from agriculture. The British Government has however an initiative planned that will, from 2018 onwards, require all new domestic buildings to incorporate zero carbon design strategies. We do admittedly need to be more responsible with our farming, but agriculture, as mentioned, isn't the largest of our concerns.

A decade ago, soya was being hailed as a superfood but
in recent years, numerous issues surrounding deforestation and its
impact on health have come to light
Once credited with power to prevent cancer and combat high
cholesterol, over the last few years, evidence that soya is far from a
superfood has begun to emerge. And it’s not just the potentially
negative health impact of the bean that has former supporters up in
arms: it’s the environmental impact. In the UK we rely heavily on soya,
or soy, and it's not just for vegetarian food. It is a hidden product in
many foods and everyday items such as soap. It is a cheap source of
protein for people as well as animals and according to Greenpeace,
80 per cent of soya worldwide is used for the livestock industry.  WWF
add that the UK consumption alone requires an area the size of Yorkshire
to be planted with soya every year. So how did soya go from super crop
to super bad?

Deforestation and slavery
Brazil,
the second biggest grower and the biggest exporter of soya, is such a
big player in the industry that there are major concerns about how this
is affecting the Amazon Rainforest. According to Greenpeace, in 2005
around 1.2 million hectares of soya was planted in the Brazilian
rainforest. Sarah Shoaka from Greenpeace's Forest Network says that
deforestation has been decreasing on the whole in Brazil since 2008.
This is mainly because of the enforcement of a soya moratorium that bans
soya produced as a result of deforestation from entering the market
place.  However, Shoraka warns that this positive trend may be changing:
'The whole of last year deforestation in the main areas for soya
including Matto Grosso – the state which is the biggest soya producer –
increased for the first time in a while.' Greenpeace think the main
reason for this is proposed changes to the controversial Forest Code
which governs how much forest each farm has to protect from the land
that they own. 'They want to give an amnesty to people that have
deforested in the past and obviously that has created a big incentive
for people to deforest before the law goes through.'

This would totally be true and accurate if the video was titled "What If The World Went Vegan," as opposed to  vegetarian. This is because being the world being vegetarian would still mean that we would be consuming dairy products. Why does this make a difference? About 85% of meat producing farms are also dairy farms. how is this? In case you didn't know, cows are manually impregnated for dairy, and aren't actually killed for meat until they are too old/weak to be used for milk anymore. This being said, if we all went vegetarian, the amount of  cows that we raise an consume would be the same- we just wouldn't slaughter them for meat  in the end. So, as this could be a more moral decision for some, but if we're talking about creating less greenhouse gasses, and preserving land that was once farmed land, it wouldn't happen, because we would still  have to maintain these farms. If we all went vegan however, this video is completely accurate, and we would be doing the world and the animals a well earned justice. I apologize for the rant, but I think that it's important that we understand the difference in the two diets and their effects on our planet! Go vegan guys, your body, mind, and the planet will thank you! <3

When comparing the amount of water to make x kg of beef, what about total economic value versus water? There is more to be gained from an animal than the meat, so comparing how much water it takes to produce just a caloric value is an unfair economic comparison. Furthermore, when comparing the caloric value of beef against say, cherries, the macro-nutrient comparison would make beef look like a more valuable product per L of water for protein (could even compare amino acids, as per WHO requirements), but cherries greater in carbohydrates...

Land used to grow crops for animals have a variety of factors that make them feasible, such as moisture, sunlight and soil of which are not equal factors for all acres of land for all crop types. It would be interesting to see what % of farmers could produce foods that replace meat consumption that currently grow for livestock consumption.

Another thing preventing everyone going vegetarian/vegan is disabilities--mental and physical. Also allergies. Some people have trouble processing certain food textures, like the texture of beans, which, as far as I know, make up a lot of the vegan/vegetarian meat substitutes. There's also people who are allergic to all legumes (which is nuts AND beans), not just nuts or peanuts, which I've heard also make up a lot of vegan/vegetarian food. Some people are also just born with things like iron deficiencies. Also, people with eating disorders do sometimes find it hard to be on a vegan/vegetarian diet. It'd be really hard for everyone to go vegan/vegetarian barring the genocide of every disabled person on the planet, and before you go saying "ok I can live with that" that is NOT an option. AMAZING!). Also,  I love meat but I love living and not having to kill to eat even more. Being very educated on food ,health,  and business I found out why our diets are so backwards and unhealthy.  To make a long story short:  Big Corporations.  You know that food triangle you learned in school?  Well, it's way off.  Because of business interest. Example:  The world heath organization (WHO) came out with studies last year proving that processed meat DOES not CAN but does cause cancer.  As most of us have seen.  However,  did you know that the food pyramid was also overviewed to see if it should be changed.  I thought the meat consumption would change at least a little due to the findings that have been out for years.  The WHO being the newest and supposed most trusted source for accurate information.  But...  NO.  Nothing changed and the triangle stayed the same.  So kinds in school who have not looked into these things personal and who's parents are not aware of the corruption at all level still think processed meat and delicious and full of protein.  Right???  When I ask people about meat that's their answer. I've been having debates with those of the vegan persuasion lately.

However, there are things to note:

A. Some arguments are arguments from pragmatism, not morality. The people that argued the practicality did not argue the morality of the vegan philosophy yet condemned people as if it were an argument from morality.

Examples:
It's a healthier lifestyle therefore it's right.
It's better for the planet, therefore it's right.
The term right is a moral term and should not be used in these context. For example, it's a healthier lifestyle or better for the planet to not smoke cigarettes, however most would agree it is not right nor wrong to smoke cigarettes. Practical =! Moral. I will always dismiss those arguments and point towards morality instead of practicality.

B. Thanks to those who do argue from morality. Of the people who argued from a moral standpoint, I've noticed that they were arguing for moral subjectivism and not objective morality. I do/did concede there would be grey areas, but argued that the whole system/principle is not a grey area as they implied. It would be similar to biology— sometimes an animal would be born with 3 heads, but we don't dismiss the entire categorization of animals for a few grey-area cases.

C. Then there are those of the anti-human stance. I'm not even going to go down that road.

If somebody wants to make the case for the vegan philosophy with objective morality, I'd be glad to read it.
1. Is the human that kills an animal immoral?
1a. If so, is the animal that kills an human immoral?
2. Does morality depend upon technology and/or time?
2a. If the breeding of plants happened 500 years later, are we immoral?
2b. If the technologies weren't available to transport plants to the colder climates, are the peoples living there immoral? Should there be more exclusions to morality beside self-defense?

+AsapScience > What If The World Went Vegetarian? Until we figure out the moral principles behind these things, it's all just arguments from pragmatism. I want to know if it's immoral or not to kill/exploit/eat/etc. animals first then work from there to determine the best course of action with said knowledge.

Prev Med. 1995 Nov;24(6):646-55.
The medical costs attributable to meat consumption.
Barnard ND1, Nicholson A, Howard JL.
Author information
Abstract
OBJECTIVE:
To estimate the medical costs that are attributable to the health effects of meat consumption.
METHODS:
The prevalence of hypertension, heart disease, cancer, diabetes, gallstones, obesity, and foodborne illness among omnivores and vegetarians are compared in studies that have controlled for other lifestyle factors, and the corresponding attributable medical costs are calculated in 1992 dollars.
RESULTS:
Direct health care costs attributable to meat consumption are estimated to be +2.8-8.5 billion for hypertension, +9.5 billion for heart disease, +0-16.5 billion for cancer, +14.0-17.1 billion for diabetes, +0.2-2.4 billion for gallbladder disease, +1.9 billion for obesity-related musculoskeletal disorders, and +0.2-5.5 billion for foodborne illness. The total direct medical costs attributable to meat consumption for 1992 are estimated at +28.6-61.4 billion.
CONCLUSION:
Health care costs attributable to meat consumption are quantifiable and substantial.

-Dr. Z.

Does this mean that some people simply cannot handle the lifestyle? Of course. Because some people cannot handle eating the proper amount and are than basically not getting enough nutrients to sustain themselves. But even going from eating meat 2-3 times a day everyday down to maybe once a day everyday or even to just a few times a week is much better. People need to open their minds to new possibilities. Yes, people are living longer but do you want to be living longer while on handfuls of medications that are keeping you alive? How you eat while you are younger can affect how you live out your last year's. Think long term, think for yourself, the life you want now and for the future.
Not one lifestyle choice is right for everyone, not one style is the correct or wrong style.

I don't think vegetarianism is the way forward but there are things we can do to reduce the effect of meat consumption. Primarily I think this will involve replacing many of the meat products used in processed goods with protein from other sources like Quorn or insects. I'm a vegetarian and I have no beef (pun intended) with people eating meat. However I do have a huge problem with factory farming, fish farms, and the food they feed the live stock for health, political, and environmental reasons. My goal is never to convert people into vegetarians at all ,but if they asked me of my opinion I would encourage them to not make meat the main course of most of their meals and to keep in mind factory farms. Again I would never push someone to become vegetarian, I for one think its awesome for people to hunt their own meals or fish their own meals as long as the animal is destructive or an invasive species.
