The problem is people want to only eat meat, or only eat vegetables, but there is a balance. While meats like beef and pork should be avoided, chicken, turkey, and fish are good sources of protein as compared to beef and whatever vegans eat.

Why is it that we can't just have a properly balanced diet? You have the two extremes of Vegans and We need Meaters. Then you have the non-extremists of Vegetarians and the rest of society who just like meat. But we don't really have a balanced area in the middle... Limiting our meat intake is good, but... being mean to others is worse. As a person I actually would like to be a pescetarian because I prefer fish  to meat, but I can't due to expenses, over-fishing, and being dependent on others at this time. So it's odd for me when we consider what should be the norm, because we already have ideas of what the norm should be. Some think the world should go ahead and become vegan. Others think the world should stay the way it is. Yes, there are benefits to both options, but there are also costs. In my personal opinion, we need to look at alternative options than the two above. Maybe that's somewhere in between rather than one extreme or the other.

Lacks quite alot of important facts and provides bit too much misinformation.
Bulk of CO2 is consumed and oxygen produced by phytoplankton. Trees are just a part of it.
Farming animals is possible in regions too hostile/cold seasons for full range of food producing plants/vegetables/fruits.
To get all the required nutrients and amino acids from plants - you need to eat fairly wide range of them - and not all of it is easily available worldwide and especially at a affordable price. Requires more preparation and is way harder to preserve and transport globally. Most plants lose taste and vitamins after treatment or freezing.
Crops are vulnerable to parasites, infections, diseases, insects and weather - can easily cause massive scale famine and starvation.
Which also means increasingly wider use of pesticides and preservatives to keep plants shelf worthy longer and look better and have higher yields.

This is video is so one sided. I think they forget that native Prarie grasslands are a huge part of the worlds carbon storage. Grasslands store and utilize as much carbon as forests in North America. Not to mention the negative effects of completely disrupting the grasslands ecosystem by eliminating the grazers (cattle). Buffalo use to roam the prairies and consume the grass to keep it healthy. Have you ever seen a lawn that goes un-mowed and unkept? Weeds and other invasive plants move in and choke out the grass because grass by nature is made to be grazed. Its a symbolic relationship between grazers and the grass. So there are no more buffalo roaming the prairies, right? Farmers and ranchers now use livestock to manage and keep the grass healthy. Its sustainable beef that makes the difference. Being a steward to the land. Farmers and ranchers have respect for the soil, because they know first hand what it can give and what it can take away for you. So next time bash my cows and calves for farting, please complete all your research before coming to your so obvious one sided conclusion. #farmersfeedtheworld

Being a meat lover for the vast majority of my life, I never thought I would become vegan. The process was slow over the period of a year. I began cutting out certain meats, like pork, then beef, then chicken, then fish. Many of these were replaced with vegetarian meat substitutes, which can be very tasty if you get the right products. I am dairy intolerant, so it was not too difficult to cut dairy down gradually until I consumed no dairy. Eggs were the only thing left, so I cut those out last. Becoming vegetarian or vegan should not be treated like some special diet you go on and suffer while you crave animal products. The appropriate way IMHO, is to completely change on the inside so that those cravings no longer exist. For me, this was a very personal internal decision that came as a result of many influences. These influences include watching animal farm documentaries, researching the science about whether the human body is geared for carnivore/omnivore/herbivore, etc. The biggest factor for me was a spiritual awakening as I like to call it. I only share why I am vegan because all of my friends and family think I am crazy and don't understand. To each their own.

I am a student that recently did a giant project with my school about climate change. We rented a building owned by Vestas, a large wind energy company. My project was about the methane gas emissions from animal agriculture and how it's tied to climate change. This video was one of the most informational and helpful sources that I've seen and I wished I could have shared it the audience I was presenting too. The numbers are staggering, and everyone really needs to take this seriously.
  Many large environmental conservation organizations don't even mention animal agriculture as being a problem. Please help spread the word! You can also do half a year as a vegan or a vegetarian, but meatless Mondays, (sorry to say) don't make an impact on the big picture. This is a great experiment, but I have to say that it's very different from what I experienced…

I decided to become vegetarian literally overnight this summer (for environmental reasons), and it was actually very easy. I wasn't sure at all that I'd be able to do it for real, or for more than a couple of months, but I've only made a few exceptions since then. Of course I did (and still do!) sometimes crave for a good steak or sushi, but it’s quite easy to get enough protein and stuff with eggs, beans etc. And there are more and more vegetarian options available everywhere (in restaurant menus as well as online easy recipes etc), so you can still eat enjoyable and tasteful stuff :)
Even if I lost some weight without trying, I never felt weak and actually I’ve never felt healthier than I do today.

So if you’re thinking about going vegetarian just try it, I think it really depends on your metabolism, habits and taste, and can be far easier than you thought! And if it’s not the case, you can still start with just reducing your meat (& fish) consumption :)

Interestingly, its monoculture that is the problem.  Most farmers are either animal or plant farmers. Separating the two makes for the seriously biological imbalance.  Livestock has the benefit of converting food we can't eat like grass into food we can eat, and their waste helps restore nutrients to the soil that separated farming does with heavy chemical fertilizers.  On top of that most of the methane produced is because we feed the cow corn, instead of their natural grass which their gut microbes aren't very good at breaking down.    Less meat, grass fed meat and more sustainable meat is what we must have in the future whether everyone switches to vegetarian or not.  Insects and vat grown meat are also areas that may seem wrong a gross but will probably replace bad polluting animal farming practices as the true price of animal farming and demand goes up.
The water that is saved by growing more vegateales can be used to make the land -initially used for grazing -more fertile.

I eat hardly any meat but I am not a vegetarian. Two points I miss in the video:
1.) Mass animal "production" is not only bad for the environment (methan, etc.) but also the way how the majority of the animals are treated is cruel. Chickens, both for egg and meat production, cattle, and pigs live in prison like conditions. Turkeys are pumped up with drugs to stay alive and also live side-by-side having hardly any space to move. Cows are breed so that they produce a maximum milk output (leading to various illnesses, pain, ...). Thankfully more and more farmers see the animal as a living being and provide them better living conditions.
2.) There are certain vitamins which cannot (or only with special drug substitution) be produced by/from plants but only from animal products such as meat, eggs, or milk (this is important for vegans).

Yes!! Good video. Just one thing I disagree with: "Animals farmers would lose their jobs." This is one of the most silly arguments that are used in society today. Suppose we would discuss whether to abolish slavery and someone says "But the slave owners would lose their jobs!" Ok, in the type of economic system we have today, it's not easy to just get a new job, but we cannot justify unmoral and wasteful practices with that argument. People will have to transition to new occupations even if it's not completely straightforward. Otherwise we get totally stuck in old habits which may be unmoral and with time we may even become indifferent to it. We have to move forward. But you correctly pointed out that a move to vegetarianism will be a gradual process, so it wouldn't really be a problem. But even if it wouldn't be a gradual process, it would still be the right thing to do. It may be hard to find another job but that has more to do with an inefficient economic system, but that's another discussion.

Animal agriculture is an extremely destructive industry. Most of the crops we grow is used to feed the animals we eat. Half the antibiotics we make is given to the animals we eat. Not to mention the enormous amount of water needed for drinking and cleaning, as well as the pollution from the animals themselves and from the waste after slaughter. The effects of animal agriculture make the environmental effects of the "dirty industries" and transportation look like child's play. Nobody wants to talk about it because whenever vegetarianism/veganism is introduced, meat eaters shove it away. Just six months ago, I was one of these people. It's time that we reach inward and find some humility and responsibility. Our individual demands for meat are what drive the industry...you don't even have to give up meat completely. Just cut back two, three days a week. Anything helps. We have a responsibility not to destroy the only earth we're ever going to get.

My issue is that there is a ridiculous, almost propaganda, skew to this video. What would the impact on the planet be if we woke up tomorrow and everyone was a vegetarian. Where or how would we ever find the actually land area to grow crops to support the 7+ billion people on this planet? Not just in relation to feeding everyone, but if you want to match the calorie intake of a diet with meat products you're going to have to eat a heck of a lot of food, ie; have to plant more to make up for the difference. I wouldn't know where to begin to attempt to run the numbers to see what kind of space this would actually take, but I will say I was extremely disappointed that this, an important aspect of this hypothetical, was not included in the video. It ignores the idea that a completely vegetarian human race might actually be bad for the planet, let alone our species itself.

"So are there any downsides to a vegetarian diet?"

First, what they are describing is a vegan diet. Second, it is interesting they don't mention the significant downside of no natural plant based source for Vitamin B12.

I think that this needs some numbers attached to it... arable land usage in particular. Remember that grazing animals can be raised on land entirely incapable of supporting crops... In fact animals fed with grain are only a tiny proportion of livestock world wide. Their wastes are also the largest source of soil improvement available; particularly in poorer countries. The growth of livestock is still technically carbon neutral if you disregard land clearing, too. In fact; sustainable grazing using holistic land management makes livestocking a carbon sink and improves soil quality.

In order to claim that vegetarianism would be an improvement, you would first have to confirm that comparable density of kilojoules can be produced per square metre of land, corrected for the quality of land (crops only grow in high quality land), the existing biodiversity of arable land (most new land suitable for crops is currently forest), the amount and availability of water in use (evaporative losses are much lower for livestock... and livestock can be successfully raised in remote areas like savanna and tundra without much water), the fallibility of crops compared with livestock (crops tend to be much less reliable); the year-round production of food (kilojoule production density is much lower over winter), and the availability of necessary nutrient like vitamins B, bioavailable iron, the full range of bioavailable amino acids, sufficient HDLs and saturated fats. Without very solid numbers on these issues; it's very difficult to judge the merits of vegetarianism.

Oh; and there are the potential health impacts for fetal development and maternal morbidity in a low-meat diets... that's a concern. As with anything; moderation is healthy.

Let's remember not to be too "first world" about this, too.

Plus, the biomass and average net primary productivity of rainforests and coral reefs are decreasing because of cultivated lands for crops (for animals and humans). Coral reefs have almost 2.5kg/area/year of net primary productivity and rainforests 2.25kg/area/year; whereas cultivated land has only around 0.65kg/area/year, which is the equivalent amount to that of temperate grass lands.

For those that feel they should dictate what others eat, I would like to say a few things.
1. All things that die are eaten unless the corpse is purposely preserved. Animals, insects, and microorganisms will eat what they can, reducing the corpse to bone.
2. Veganism/vegitarism is not the "only choice" for living on this planet. Carnivores and omnivores would not have evolved if that where the case.
3. Eating meat is not the same as killing an animal. It takes much more will to actively harm another living thing than it does simple benefiting from it's dead. Just look at hawks and vultures.
4. Not all animals are as innocent as you make them out to be. A moose (herbivore) will stomp you to death if it thinks you're invading it's territory and your cat and/or will eat your corpse if no other food source is available. (cats will wait like a day before they stop caring)

The reason this argument fails is simple, but also sad.  Because animals are fed corn, and corn is a high performing crop (calories per square km yield).  In order for us to match the result we'd be stuck growing only crops which match the calories per square km yield which are currently feeding the animals we eat.  Minus an efficiency conversion factor.  You can take all your vegetarian dream crops and throw them away because they are calorie deficient, all the classic salad vegetables go right out the window, and you are left with grains etc the very things we grow now that we don't want to eat because they taste awful and yet cows will eat them, and we like to eat cows.  So once you do the analysis you realize, ultimately, livestock are flavor conversion machines, which take high calorie yield crops which are not tasty and convert them (with losses) into tasty food.  If you want to live in a vegetarian world, yes it's FAR more efficient for the planet and it's people, but your dreams of delicious salad are a myth and you will be required to eat a lot of calorie dense crops which aren't all that interesting.  Most vegetarians are just so clueless that they believe that the world can survive off of endless square km of crops of cucumbers, tomatoes and salad greens, when in fact that ends up killing the entire population of the planet in short order.  So your life becomes "good morning, which nutrient rich gruel paste should I inject this morning?"  Enjoy.

"I'm a vegan"

If this were to happen, farmers all over the world would lose a lot of jobs. For my example , I'm using Ireland. Here Crops aren't very dominant because most soils aren't suited for crop growing. You need a free draining soil or sandy soil for crops here. Our wet climate makes it so that if a crop is grown in wet soil or clay soil then the seed may drown. (Seeds need 3 things for germination: oxygen, heat and water. You need a balance of all of them). Places like Connacht in the west of Ireland or the Mezzogiorno in Italy don't grow any crops as the soil is too shallow or other reasons that I won't go into. If everyone in the world went vegetarian, Connachts main industries of beef, sheep and fish would become redundant and cause even greater unemployment. This would happen all over the world. Even though he says some places can go back to grasslands or forests then what happens to the farmers who owned that land and lived off that land for survival.

Also on another note barley which is used for brewing called malten barley. It is also used for animal feed. You need very good soil and a lot of care to make this malten barley. (I won't go into any particulars here but trust me malten barley is a lot of work.) When malten barley isn't up to a brewers standards then it is used as animal feed. This is so the farmer still gets money for something he worked on for half a year.

So that's more or less it(Simplified) so hopefully we don't all become vegetarian.

This really glosses over some of the less attractive details of everyone being vegetarian... eliminating industrial scale cattle could be introducing more problems than it solves.

1) There is physically not enough land on the planet to grow food for 7billion people.
2) You can't have large scale agriculture without massive amounts of fertilizer. There won't be enough manure to cover the farms to grow the crops.
3) The topsoil is currently disappearing (or completely depleted in some areas) because of over-farming and not allowing animals to graze on farmlands.

I'm pretty sure all of these problems really stem from the first one though.

Too many people, not enough land. No easy fix for either.

The argument to go vegan and especially vegetarian are just as flawed as the argument to stay omnivorous (eat both plants and animals).

To be clear this is from an Animal Science student going for vet tech who fell in love with a cow calf I trained once. She was like a puppy.

First off animal farming is not the enemy. Big industrial farming is. Small farms tend to take much better care of their animals and for the most part the small farm animals live better lives than wild ones. They are vaccinated and dewormed, kept at healthy weights, and humane laws are in place to protect them. And surely the way the animals are slaughtered are better than wolves or tigers etc. ripping into them and eating them while they're still alive. And let me remind you that in the wild female animals also have babies every year. As long as they're in heat and a male's around they're going to get pregnant.

Now there is room for improvements but same could be said for how we treat other people and with recycling etc. too.

Second, meat is a good and fast way to get protein. Sure you can get it from other sources but if you've got a fussy kid or adult they're going to end up popping pills to get what they're missing in their diet and I know vegetarians that have to do that anyway. It is harder to balance your diet this way and to me popping pills isn't any healthier than just eating a natural balanced diet and watching how much you eat.

Third - For plants we need fertilizer and that often comes from our farm animals. Also, many crops are still showered with poison to kill off the bugs feeding on them so how healthy is it really when this poison washes into rivers and ends up in our food? Crop land often still isn't well taken care of and can become so overused they cannot grow much on it anymore.

Fourth - We'd still need a lot of land for crop growth. Also, as the human population grows we're just going to take over our new found space anyway.

Fifth - Where'd the now useless meat animals go? We'd have to slaughter them all or let them use of the land they're on until they die which wastes money and would mean more methane poops. Farmers would lose jobs, yes. Vets and states people would also lose jobs. Animals used for eggs and milk eventually can't produce anymore - what do farmers do with them after? They can't afford to keep animals that don't produce. Not to mention all the products made from animals - especially MEDICINE! So no, we can't just get rid of all the farm animals.

Sixth, nobody ever think about how much animals are out in nature? We don't count how much methane they're giving off, do we? Just because they're wild. Humans are the factor causing the issues with farm animals. BTW, many farms are starting to recycle methane - meaning they feed their animals with their crops and put their poop on the new crops and so on.

Seventh - 15% is still low. I imagine people create the other 85%. No seriously, anyone look at the garbage we create and the methane that gives off? How much water we consume and use to shower every single day? How much waste we make, both poop and food waste? Did you know many pigs are fed the food we don't eat in restaurants that otherwise would get dumped in the landfill?

When farming is done right, it's not that damaging. We just need more people to do it the right way. Our animals aren't the problem, we are.
Vegetarian is bullshit you still have cheese and milk. Plant based nutrition would yield the most benefits.

It is actually possible to turn pasture into a mix of forest and animal grazing grounds already. It makes for healthier animals (at least mentally) and gives them somewhere to take cover from wind, sun and rain. It's all about balancing out the amount of grass and trees in a smart way.

And there's HUGE areas which only grows crops too meant for human consumption in one way or another. This would only grow and grow as more people become vegetables. (intended)
Unlike grazing grounds, you don't want trees on cropland.

Also, as already mentioned in the video, animals can turn deserts into arable lands. Crops on the other hand turns arable lands into deserts.

One thing we really should be doing more of is letting the grounds rest from time to time. Turn farmland that has been worked too much back into forests for a while. This give the land time to recover rather than continually wash out into the oceans. The same goes for certain grazing areas, let it grow into forest and then let animals start the reclamation once the time has come to use the land again.

Finally, why i will never become a straight up vegetarian, i do think we as humans on the global scale both consume TOO much meat but more importantly WASTE too much meat.
For every steak you eat, another equal amount of meat is wasted in one way or another. If we could keep waste to a minimum and reduced the average meat consumption we could simply halve livestocks across the globe and reclaim those lands for better uses. Such as cycling cropland with forests and/or giving the remaining livestock more land to graze on which will benefit both them AND us.

In many parts of the world, particularly poor countries, people often raise animals in semi-urban environments that are too small to raise crops. Or where there isn't sufficient light and soil to grow crops. Such as people raising raising chickens in a coop on their roof. Or raising pig or a goat in a courtyard. These animals are largely fed on scraps and vegetable matter that humans can't digest and they provide a vital source of protean and calories. If these people went vegetarian then they would likely suffer form malnutrition as they couldn't afford to replace the protean and calories with the vegetarian equivalent (The animals are being fed from waste so their food is essentially free).

If we stopped farming billions of animals currently used for livestock would disappear.

True sort of, and this is the big issue for ethical vegetarian as the conversion from our current diets to global vegetarianism would necessitate the euthanasia of billions of animals as no one would raise them without economic benefit; save for fringe examples of hobbyists. It would need to be done as releasing these animals to the wild would be an ecological disaster on the scale of previous extinction events, far worse potentially than continuing or increasing livestock production. look at the issue of domestic animals going feral currently then multiply it by several orders of magnitude. Some animals such as sheep, goats, and llama may still be viable livestock for use of their hair, and others for by products such as eggs or milk, but it would still require a massive reduction of current livestock populations as not all livestock are useful for those purposes.

Unused farm land for growing feed would return to it's natural state.

False, that land would simply be re-purposed to grow crops for humans, arable land is too valuable to simply be allowed to go wild.

The water used in producing meat is 5x that of fruit 7x that of vegetable and 20x that of cereal grains

Yes, but lets remember that these numbers are cumulative from growing feed as well as watering the animals themselves. Also, it's not a zero sum equation, that water can be reclaimed and recycled and a large amount of the impact on the hydro cycle is already mitigated through use of water reclamation techniques, further improvements to which can bolster this effect.

And now a personal note

Cut the bullshit already. While this is by far one of the most fair videos on environmental vegetarianism I've see so far, in that you actually take a look at some the positives and negatives of global vegetarianism (Hank Green is notorious for only presenting the positives), I still smell the stink of guilt and shame over eating meat throughout this video, for instance your sound track is a downbeat piano tune as opposed to the more upbeat track in most of your other videos. If you feel that not eating meat would benefit humanity and the environment, then by all means, stop eating meat, no one has any problem with vegetarians themselves.The problems lie in the bitching about it to other people expecting them to pick up your slack. It is hypocritical behavior on your part and insulting, reductive, prescriptivist, moralizing to the rest of us. Remember that this is a science channel first and foremost, and while I recognize that you are human, you should be reporting the facts, in an entertaining manner, without bias, to the best of your ability. This is the standard to which many of your audience hold you, and when you deviate it is glaringly dissonant.

The problem per se isn't eating meat, it's how the industry handles it. When you buy animal products (and by-products) from local farms you help the environment and local economy. Plus farms practice a more a traditional (and thus clean and humane) way of producing- meaning you food will not be filled with nasty things that harm you and the environment. On top of that, in farms animals are well-treated all their life until they're killed for consumation- no hormones, no mistreat, no horryfing ways of life. The solution would be to stop buying from big industries (those that use feedlots, slaughterhouses and such) and start buying from small, local producers. Esentially, go from classic to organic. Sadly, organic food is usually a lot more expensive because small producers don't really have a chance against big companies

I am vegetarian for over 20 years so on board but there is a component missing here. Where would the nitrogen, potassium and phosphorous come from to grow the huge amounts of modern vegetables we eat? Nutrient rich soil is made in large part from blood, bone and shit, aka manure, bone/blood meal etc...Where I live fish compost is often used also. Right know in organic growing those come from mostly animal by-products. If we don't used chemical fertilizers deriving from oil products, which damage the environment, we need to get those minerals into the soil to grow large tracks of vegetables somehow. Remember our veggies now are for the most part not native to their current area or soil.

Animals do not roam free, shitting and dying where ever they like as in the past, and we also don't roam free moving from place to place to allow areas to go fallow. There are 7 billion+ people, most of them sedentized, and they need to get nutrients into the ground somehow if they want to grow food locally. Would human manure be able to meet the soil requirements for every area? Wouldn't that be subject to diminishing returns? Should we grind up and bury people in gardens instead of cemeteries? What would happen to the local food movement because some areas in the world just can't produce any high density protein organically without utilizing animals in some way. Should they be importing veggie burgers or even just sacks of beans from factories far away that use chemical fertilizers to grow beans on large mono-culture tracks of land? Should we be pushing for more GMOs? Veganic growing does exist but it requires 30% more land because basically you are growing compost for several years on a portion of your farm. You need to have some native soil fertility to begin with to do that.

It would be interesting to see those issues addressed. It seems people think we can get the same vegetables we are used to eating while stepping out side the shitting and dying part of the food web of which we are part. Right now in, organic growing at least, we use animal waste, and the blood and bone of animals to fill that gap for soil nutrients that in turn give us our big fat heads of organic broccoli. If they weren't there, what would we use?

Humans are omnivores, we're not meant for a strictly vegetarian diet. That said, people should reduce their meat consumption for many of the reasons mentioned here, as well as for health reasons. Meat should mainly be a side dish, or used sparingly as a flavoring with/for pasta, rice, etc. Meat as a main course should be an occasional thing, much as I love a good steak or a bacon cheeseburger. We've got teeth for cutting and chewing meat, but let's not forget about those flat ones in the back for grinding up plant material.

And because I know people are going to ask; yes, my eating habits match my philosophy. Also, I could never go completely vegan. I'd be ok without meat and not be too upset about it, but I'll be damned if I'll live in a world where I can't eat eggs and dairy (if I've got it backwards and it's vegans who eat eggs and dairy and vegetarians who don't, then that's what I mean).
